title: Domain 4: IT Change Control (4.5)
description: Covers IT infrastructure change control, software change control, CI/CD (continuous integration, continuous delivery, continuous deployment), production vs. staging environments, rollback plans, maintenance windows, ITIL, DevOps, DevSecOps, releases, and customer notifications.

questions.question: An action taken to restore a system to the last known good state after a failed release is called a:
questions.explanation: A rollback restores a system to its last known good state. It is the recovery method when a release fails, allowing the team to fix the issue without continued impact on end users.

questions.question: A requirement for a new cloud migration solution is automated rollback. Why is this significant?

options.text: It eliminates the need for testing
It restores the system to a previous working state, enabling recovery from failed releases without impacting end users
It replaces the need for a staging environment

questions.explanation: Rollback restores a system to a previous working state. It is your recovery method when a release fails — you can roll back the system and fix the release without impacting the end user. A rollback plan should be prepared before any release.

questions.question: Scheduled periods of system outages that an organization uses to perform system maintenance and deploy releases are called:
questions.explanation: Maintenance windows are scheduled periods of system outages used to perform system maintenance and deploy releases. They are planned in advance and communicated to stakeholders and users to minimize disruption.

questions.question: A software development method in which code updates are tested and rapidly committed to a development or build server / code repository is called:
questions.explanation: Continuous integration (CI) is a method where code updates are tested and rapidly committed to a development or build server/code repository. It ensures code changes are frequently merged and validated.

questions.question: A software development method in which application and platform requirements are frequently tested and validated for immediate availability is called:
questions.explanation: Continuous delivery is a method where application and platform requirements are frequently tested and validated for immediate availability. The code is always in a deployable state, but deployment to production is a manual decision.

questions.question: A software development method in which application and platform updates are rapidly committed to production automatically is called:
questions.explanation: Continuous deployment automatically pushes application and platform updates to production after passing automated tests. Unlike continuous delivery, there is no manual approval step before production deployment.

questions.question: A practice that integrates software development and systems operations into a single discipline is called:
questions.explanation: DevOps is a combination of software development and systems operations. It integrates development and operations teams to improve collaboration, speed up delivery, and increase reliability of software releases.

questions.question: A practice that integrates software development, security operations, and systems operations is called:
questions.explanation: DevSecOps integrates development, security, and operations. It extends DevOps by embedding security practices throughout the software development lifecycle rather than treating security as a separate phase.

questions.question: A development team insists on having at least three environments: development, beta, and production. Why would developers want multiple environments?

options.text: To separate development and testing from production, reducing risk to the customer and source code
To confuse stakeholders with complex architecture
To slow down the release process intentionally

questions.explanation: Multitiered environments reduce risk by separating development and test operations from the production environment. Multiple people can work on the product without placing the customer or source code at risk.

questions.question: An IT best practice framework emphasizing the alignment of IT Service Management (ITSM) with business needs is called:
questions.explanation: ITIL (IT Infrastructure Library) is an IT best practice framework emphasizing the alignment of IT Service Management with business needs. First developed in 1989 by the UK government, ITIL 4 was released in 2019.

questions.question: How does IT infrastructure change control differ from project change control?

options.text: IT change control manages changes to production systems and infrastructure; project change control manages changes to project scope, schedule, and budget
Project change control only applies to agile projects
IT change control does not require approval

questions.explanation: IT infrastructure change control manages changes to production systems, infrastructure, and live environments. Project change control manages changes to a project's scope, schedule, and budget. Both require formal processes, but they operate in different contexts.

questions.question: Formal communications to make customers or end users aware of system events that could impact their experience or ability to use the system are called:
questions.explanation: Customer notifications are formal communications to make customers or end users aware of system events — such as maintenance windows, outages, or releases — that could impact their experience or ability to use the system.

questions.question: The process of restructuring application code to improve design without changing external behavior is called:
questions.explanation: Refactoring is the process of restructuring application code so that the same functionality is provided by different programming methods. It improves the application's design without affecting its external behavior.

questions.question: Which THREE of the following are components of a CI/CD pipeline?

options.text: Continuous integration (automated code merging and testing)
Continuous delivery (code always in a deployable state)
Continuous auditing (automated compliance checks of project finances)

questions.explanation: CI/CD consists of continuous integration (automated testing and merging), continuous delivery (deployable code ready on demand), and continuous deployment (automated production releases). Continuous auditing and staffing are not CI/CD components.

questions.question: Match each CI/CD term to its correct description.

pairs.right: Code updates are tested and rapidly committed to a build server or code repository
Application is frequently tested and validated for immediate availability on demand
Updates are automatically committed to production after passing automated tests
Restoring a system to its last known good state after a failed release

questions.explanation: CI merges and tests code frequently. CD (delivery) keeps code in a deployable state. CD (deployment) auto-pushes to production. Rollback is the safety net when any release fails — restoring the last working version.
